tossups.question: Galen Strawson defended this philosopher’s view that identity depends on psychological continuity, and thus on “consciousness, not on substance.” Galen’s father Peter reused a term coined by this philosopher to describe both nominal and real essences, which cannot be measured. This coiner of the term “sortal” adopted a “historical, plain method” to demonstrate how the mind combines ideas received from nature, which are (*) simple, into complex ideas. He distinguished between primary and secondary qualities in that essay, in which he claimed that humans are not born with innate knowledge, a view often described as a tabula rasa or “blank slate.” For 10 points, name this author of Essay Concerning Human Understanding who presented a political philosophy in Two Treatises of Government.
tossups.answer: John Locke <ML, Phil/Thought>

tossups.question: A 2018 paper by a team in Bangalore reported an example of these materials comprised of gold and silver until questions were raised about strange repeating noise. Observation of an exponential increase in the band gap of vanadium supported one theory of these materials, which predicts that bound states within them have lower energy than the Fermi energy due to long-range interactions coupled by (*) lattice vibrations. Two of these materials are separated by a thin barrier in magnetometers called SQUIDs, which operate via the Josephson effect. Materials with this property expel magnetic fields in the Meissner effect. Phonons mediate the bindings of electrons into Cooper pairs according to the BCS theory of, for 10 points, what materials with zero resistance to electric current?
tossups.answer: superconductors [accept word forms like superconductivity or superconducting materials] <RN, Physics>

tossups.question: A map of this city produced in Italian by Sebastian Munster changed its city plan to a European-style grid. The “stone of the twelve angles” was an archaeological relic found in this city and exemplifies its builders’ common technique of cutting stones geometrically to do away with the need for mortar. This city is defended by the fortress of Sacsaywaman (“sock-say-wah-MAHN”), which forms the “head” of its (*) puma-shaped layout. This city marked the point of division into four “quarters” including Antisuyu and Collasuyu (“ko-la-SOO-yoo”). A temple called the Coricancha was one of the most important landmarks in this city and was used to worship the sun god Inti. This city was sacked after a loss at the Battle of Cajamarca (“ka-ha-MAR-ka”) for Atahualpa (“ah-tah-WALL-pah”). For 10 points, name this capital of the Inca Empire.
tossups.answer: Cusco [or Cuzco or Qosqo] <JM, World History>

tossups.question: A king sacrificed nine sons to this god to extend his own life by 140 years, but his subjects understandably refused to let him sacrifice his tenth, so that king died of old age. This god, who received those sacrifices from Aun, is mocked by his own son for using the magic wand Gambanteinn in a flyting, or insult contest, in which this god appears as the ferryman Harbard. This god turned into a snake to slither through a hole drilled in a mountain by (*) Baugi (“BOW-gee”), thus gaining access to Suttung’s lair. By doing so, he sought to acquire a magic substance mixed with the blood of Kvasir, the mead of poetry. This god embalmed the head of Mimir, at whose well he sacrificed an eye to gain wisdom. The ravens Hugin and Munin belong to, for 10 points, what “All-Father” and chief Norse god?
tossups.answer: Odin [accept Wotan or Wuotan or Wodan or Woden] <ML, Myths/Legends>

tossups.question: An Indian-born immigrant to this country included a scene in which a helicopter causes a giant cutout of a leader to topple on civilians in a novel about the tailor Dina Dalal set during the Emergency. A forensic pathologist discovers a recently-buried skeleton in a novel from this country titled Anil’s Ghost. While stealing military documents, a morphine-addicted thief from this country is caught and has his thumbs chopped off, inspiring his name (*) Caravaggio. A copy of Herodotus’s Histories leads the injured title character of a novel from this country to recall his past experiences while being cared for by the nurse Hana in a bombed-out Italian villa during World War II. For 10 points, what country is home to the Sri Lankan-born author of The English Patient, Michael Ondaatje (“on-DAH-chee”)?
tossups.answer: Canada (The first novel is Rohinton Mistry’s A Fine Balance.) <AR, Long Fiction>

tossups.question: An A minor concerto for this instrument opens with “E A, [pause] E F,” [pause] ends with a gigue (“jeeg”)-like movement in 9/8 (“nine-eight”) time, and was arranged into its composer’s keyboard concerto in G minor. Among the Brandenburg Concertos, the sixth one uniquely [emphasize] does not feature this instrument. A four-bar ostinato based on the romanesca chord progression is the subject of the lengthy fifth and final movement of a solo piece by J. S. Bach in D minor for this instrument that presents 64 variations. That (*) chaconne (“shuh-CON”) for this instrument was called “one of the greatest achievements of any man” by Joshua Bell, and features numerous double and triple stops. Bach wrote an E major concerto and a set of six sonatas and partitas for this solo instrument. For 10 points, name this smallest common string instrument.
tossups.answer: violin <WA, Classical/Opera>

tossups.question: A protein hypothesized to control this process was originally posited by Mikhail Chailakhyan (“chy-lahkh-YAHN”); that protein forms a heterodimer with the transcription factor FD. In response to low temperature, the long noncoding RNA COLDAIR induces competence for this process by silencing FLC, which de-represses FT, FD, and SOC1. GIGANTEA and CONSTANS link this process to circadian rhythms, whose timing separates short-day and long-day organisms. Three sets of overlapping homeotic genes drive this process in the (*) apical meristem in the ABC model of it. The calyx and corolla are formed during this process, which also forms reproductive structures that contain pollen. For 10 points, name this process in which a structure containing stamens, pistils, sepals, and petals forms during angiosperm development.
tossups.answer: flower development [or flowering; or florescence; accept equivalents; prompt on blossoming or blooming; prompt on development or plant development] <EM, Biology: Dev/Plant>

tossups.question: A poet in this language mourned a woman’s death in a poem that describes his lyre “turned at last to tears.” A hunchbacked poet used this language to describe how a speaker’s “thoughts are drowned” in the “immensity” he encounters while sitting on a “solitary hill” in a poem titled “The Infinite.” A poem about “coward Love” that “doth reign and live within my thought” was translated from this language by both the Earl of Surrey and Sir (*) Thomas Wyatt. In a sonnet in this language, love catches the speaker “weaponless” when the “sun’s ray was darkened” on Good Friday. A collection in this language is addressed to “you who hear the sound, in scattered rhymes” and includes many of the author’s namesake sonnets. For 10 points, Laura (“LAO-rah”) is the addressee of poems in what language used by Petrarch?
tossups.answer: Italian <NC, Poetry>

tossups.question: When security in this country did not check the violin cases of several Japanese musicians, the latter pulled out assault rifles from the cases and opened fire in an airport, as they were part of the Japanese Red Army. In this country, an incident in which a truck ran over four people at the Jabalia (“ja-BALL-ya”) refugee camp began a revolt that started a prolonged “humiliation” according to New Historian Benny Morris. A mass eviction in this country is commemorated on May 15 as (*) Nakba Day, which comes right after this country’s commemoration of its independence on May 14, 1948. This country blew up a fourth of Uganda’s air force in Operation Entebbe (“en-TEB-ay”), in which its troops liberated a plane from PFLP hijackers. Two Intifadas were fought in, for 10 points, what country that employs the Mossad spy agency?
tossups.answer: Israel [or State of Israel or Medinat Yisra’el; prompt on Palestine; do not accept or prompt on “Gaza Strip” or “West Bank”] (The first clue refers to the Lod Massacre.) <WA, Commonwealth/Misc>

tossups.question: A man in this city is seen admiring a voyeuristic painting while window shopping with his wife in the photograph Sidelong Glance. The graffiti and nightlife of this city were documented by a Hungarian immigrant who was dubbed its “Eye,” Brassaï (“brah-SY”). Two actors staged an impromptu passionate embrace for a photo taken in this city titled Kiss By the City Hall. Near a (*) train station in this city, an artist captured a man jumping from a ladder into a shallow pool of water, illustrating the “decisive moment” he sought while photographing its streets. Early photographers who worked in this city include Nadar and the inventor of the daguerreotype (“da-GAIR-oh-type”). For 10 points, name this European capital, where many photos are taken of a thousand-foot-tall tower built by Gustav Eiffel.
tossups.answer: Paris <RK, Other Arts: Photography>

tossups.question: The mysticism of this person’s theology is compared to Freudian psychoanalysis in Norman Brown’s Life Against Death, which notes how this person spent significant time contemplating the devil while on the toilet. A concept of a “second birth” is identified in this person’s life in a psychological biography that analyzes how he rejected his father’s plan for him to pursue a law career. When caught in a (*) thunderstorm, this man vowed to Saint Anne that, if he survived, he would commit his life to a monastery. This man, whose identity crisis is analyzed in Erik Erikson’s biography about him as a “young man,” proclaimed “here I stand, I can do no other” before he was denounced by Pope Leo X (“the tenth”) at the Diet of Worms. For 10 points, name this reformer who promulgated 95 theses.
tossups.answer: Martin Luther [accept Young Man Luther] <WA, Religion>

tossups.question: One model of this phenomenon predicts a “conditional convergence” in which different entities have different steady-state ratios and initial endowments, but this phenomenon is the same among them. A “balanced path” is imposed on this phenomenon in approaches that treat major determinants of it as exogenous. In a type of “accounting” named for this phenomenon, its components are broken down into such factors as the per capita stock of (*) capital, labor force participation, and residual total factor productivity. This phenomenon is only sustainable through technological progress according to one interpretation of the Solow (“solo”)–Swan model of it. An outward shift of a nation’s production–possibility frontier indicates, for 10 points, what phenomenon that is often quantified by increases in GDP?
tossups.answer: economic growth [or GDP growth; accept exogenous growth or growth accounting] <CQ, Social Science: Econ>

tossups.question: The museum dedicated to this neighborhood’s history is located in a building named after cosmetics entrepreneur Max Factor. The Waldorf Statement condemned employees who worked primarily in this neighborhood, including Edward Dmytryk and Ring Lardner, Jr.; those men were imprisoned for contempt of Congress. Sid Grauman built two “exotic-revival” buildings in this neighborhood in Egyptian and (*) Chinese styles. This neighborhood’s major product was largely unregulated until the adoption of the Hayes Code. One landmark in this neighborhood removed the suffix “LAND” to form an iconic hillside sign. The Walk of Fame is located in, for 10 points, what Los Angeles neighborhood known as the center of the Western film industry?
tossups.answer: Hollywood [prompt on Tinseltown or Westside; do not accept or prompt on “West Hollywood”] <AA, US History>

tossups.question: An essay by this author includes Gregor Samsa at negative infinity on one of many charts with a “good fortune–ill fortune” axis. This author of “Here is a Lesson in Creative Writing” frequently scribbled his signature within a sketch of himself smoking. He included drawings of a heart-shaped locket inscribed with the Serenity Prayer and a tombstone with the line “Everything was beautiful, and nothing hurt” in a novel about an optometrist from (*) Ilium, New York. This author marked deaths with the three-word phrase “So it goes” in a novel whose protagonist is kidnapped by time-travelling aliens from Tralfamadore. In that novel, this author’s recurring philanthropist Eliot Rosewater introduces the shell-shocked protagonist to Kilgore Trout’s fiction. For 10 points, name this author of Slaughterhouse-Five.
tossups.answer: Kurt Vonnegut <WA, Misc Lit>

tossups.question: An advisor to this king solved Adriaan van Roomen’s problem and also names a method of solving polynomials. Like Herbert Hoover, this king claimed that he would make sure there was “a chicken in every pot.” This king’s opponents tried to replace him with his imprisoned uncle, before this king crushed them at the Battle of Ivry (“ee-VREE”). During this king’s tenure, François Viète (“vee-ET”) broke a cipher belonging to the (*) Catholic League. The Duke of Guise (“gheez”) led an effort to prevent this king from taking the throne. This king, who promulgated religious toleration in the Edict of Nantes (“nont”), supposedly claimed “Paris is well worth a mass” to signal his willingness to convert to Catholicism. For 10 points, name this first Bourbon king of France, the victor of the “War of the Three Henrys.”
tossups.answer: Henry IV of France [accept Henry of Navarre or Henri le vert galant or Henry the Green Gallant or Good King Henry or Henry the Great; prompt on Henry or Henri] <ML, European History>

tossups.question: This element has an oxidation state of 0 in its metallocene, which is stable despite having 19 electrons. A Gamma Knife apparatus uses 201 sources of an isotope of this element in a hemispherical array. In a common introductory chemistry lab, a pink octahedral complex of this atom is converted to a tetrahedral blue complex via dehydration. A cofactor containing this element is used by an enzyme that converts homocysteine to methionine and whose deficiency leads to (*) pernicious anemia. In that cofactor, this metal is bound in a corrin ring. Glasses containing pigments of this element are used to filter light in flame tests because of their blue color. Like iron and nickel, this element is ferromagnetic. Vitamin B12 contains, for 10 points, what metal whose atomic number is 27?
tossups.answer: cobalt [prompt on Co] <RN, Chemistry>

tossups.question: This artist decorated a lunette with quotes from Psalm 106 in a painting that depicts a threatening Pharaoh and an Assyrian king. That painting, Israelites Oppressed, is included with Dogma of the Redemption in this artist’s mural cycle for the Boston Public Library, titled the Triumph of Religion. Several musicians sit against a wall on which two guitars hang in a painting by this artist in which a (*) Spanish dancer stretches out her left arm as she performs. Yet another painting by this artist shows a pale-skinned woman resting one hand on a table and using the other to grasp her black dress, one of whose straps has fallen. For 10 points, name this artist of El Jaleo (“ell hah-LAY-oh”) who scandalised viewers with his portrait of Virginie Gautreau, dubbed “Madame X.”
tossups.answer: John Singer Sargent <AR, Painting/Sculpture>

tossups.question: Travelers to the eastern part of this island often pass by an 18-foot-tall duck-shaped building appropriately called the Big Duck. “East Enders” who live in two towns on this island proposed seceding from Suffolk County to form Peconic County, which would be named for a nearby bay on which Sag Harbor lies. Summer vacationers to this island frequently take State Route 27 or the (*) Montauk Branch rail line and visit its protected Pine Barrens. Many celebrities come to this island to vacation on the Gold Coast or on a set of similarly-named resort villages on its South Fork. The MTA’s LIRR serves this island and passes through the borough of Queens. For 10 points, name this island that is home to the Hamptons and parallels the coast of Connecticut for over 100 miles.
tossups.answer: Long Island <WA, Geography>

tossups.question: This author began a play by offering a legal contract requesting that the audience’s criticism be proportional to their seat price. He created the “angry Boy” Kastril, who tries to get his sister to marry a Spanish count. In a play by this author, a Justice of Peace disguises himself as a fool to investigate an event in which a puppet lifts its clothes to refute accusations of cross-dressing. This author mocked Puritans with characters like Tribulation, Ananias, and (*) Zeal-of-the-Land Busy. In another of his plays, Dapper is blindfolded and robbed before meeting the “Queen of Fairy,” who is the prostitute Dol Common in disguise. Epicure Mammon pays Subtle to create the philosopher’s stone in that play by this author. For 10 points, name this Jacobean playwright of Bartholomew Fair and The Alchemist.
tossups.answer: Ben Jonson <NC, Drama>

tossups.question: Bob Nystrom of EA wrote a game programming ebook on these concepts. Bad programming practices called “anti” this noun can cause code smell. Roach motel, confirm-shaming, and friend spam on travel sites, Amazon, and LinkedIn are “dark” concepts of this name coined by Harry Brignull that trick users into unintended actions. Unification in Prolog is analogous to a “matching” feature of this name in functional languages like OCaml (“oh-camel”) and Haskell that decomposes data structures by (*) shape. Two chapters on pitfalls of the object-oriented paradigm precede 23 concepts of this name, such as Visitor, Singleton, and Factory, in the Gang of Four’s book on repeatable software design concepts. A Java class of this name represents a compiled regular expression, which is a template for matching strings. For 10 points, machine learning encompasses automatic recognition of what regularities in data or images?
tossups.answer: patterns [accept design patterns, dark patterns, anti-patterns, Pattern class, pattern matching, pattern recognition, or Game Programming Patterns; prompt on software design until read] <OL, Computer Science>  If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions.   Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: Two-dimensional examples of these spaces are called surfaces and include the projective plane, the torus, and the sphere. For 10 points each:
answers: saddle points [prompt on minimax points until read] <NC, Math>
parts: Name these topological spaces in which the neighborhood around every point is homeomorphic to Euclidean space.

Sard’s theorem states that for a smooth function between two manifolds, the set of these points has measure zero. In single-variable calculus, these points occur where a function’s derivative equals zero or does not exist.

In multivariable calculus, a critical point that is not a relative extremum is this kind of point, which is a minimum in one direction and a maximum in another. They are sometimes called minimax points.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about food in early England, for 10 points each.
parts: Costermongers were tasked with testing fruits and vegetables and drew their name from the Costard variety of this fruit, which sometimes names a holiday that celebrates the restoration of Charles II to the throne.

Garblers tested these goods for purity by putting them through a sieve (“siv”). These general goods were bought from the East and transported on the Silk Road and included cardamom, turmeric, and cinnamon.

Medieval Englishmen used these objects, sometimes made by putting a divot (“DIV-it”) in wooden squares and sometimes with large pieces of stale bread, in lieu of plates. Their name comes from a medieval French word for “to cut.”

bonuses.leadin: This composer’s 32 diverse piano sonatas broke many norms of his time, such as his choice to write many of them in four movements, which later became commonplace. For 10 points each:
answers: C minor [do not accept or prompt on “C”]
“Waldstein” Sonata [or Piano Sonata No. 21 in C major] <WA, Classical/Opera>
parts: Name this composer whose sonatas include “Les Adieux” (“lay zahd-YEW”) and “Moonlight.”
Beethoven used this key for both his final sonata and his Sonata Pathétique (“pah-theh-TEEK”). His pieces in this key, which are often described as “stormy,” include his Symphony No. 5.

This middle period sonata, one of Beethoven’s two in C major, opens with soft repeated block chords that are oddly restated in B-flat major in bar 5. Its second movement is an Introduzione to its Rondo finale, as its Andante favori (“fa-VO-ree”) movement was discarded and published separately.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about shitty modern art, for 10 points each.
answers: Virgin Mary [or the Virgin Mary; or Madonna; accept The Holy Virgin Mary]
parts: For his piece Artist’s Shit, Piero Manzoni sold cans of his excrement at the price of this metal, which Maurizio Cattelan used to sculpt a toilet. Gustav Klimt’s The Kiss uses a thin form of this precious metal known as “leaf.”

Chris Ofili pissed off Rudy Giuliani when he used two balls of elephant dung to prop up his portrait of this person, who is depicted surrounded by images of female buttocks cut from pornographic magazines.

This artist likely painted with the feces of his daughter Maya, whose mother Marie-Thérèse Walter he painted in Le Rêve. The cheerful Le Rêve contrasts with this artist’s portrait of his muse Dora Maar, The Weeping Woman.

bonuses.leadin: When this reaction is performed on an alkyne, it generates an enol that rapidly tautomerizes to a ketone. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this reaction that is normally used to convert alkenes into alcohols without creating a carbocation (“carbo-cat-ion”) intermediate, preventing rearrangements. After performing this reaction, the products are typically treated with sodium borohydride.
The central reagent used in oxymercuration consists of mercury bonded to two equivalents of the anion of this acid. This acid is found in vinegar.

Mercury is used in the Wolffenstein–Böters reaction to add an alcohol and three of this functional group onto benzene. In the Béchamp reduction, a benzene attached to this functional group is reduced to give aniline.

bonuses.leadin: This poem invokes the “fair nymphs of Tagus” in its introductory section, which begins by mimicking Virgil’s Aeneid. For 10 points each:
answers: in medias res [accept nonstandard in media res]
Cape of Good Hope [or Cape of Storms; prompt on Cape or Africa] <RK, Misc Lit>
parts: Name this poem in ottava rima that opens with the Greek gods watching over its protagonist Vasco de Gama. It is considered the national epic of Portugal.

After invoking the gods, Luís de Camões’s (“kah-MOISH’s”) Lusíadas parallels other epics by opening in this manner. In Ars Poetica, Horace coined this three-word Latin term to describe when a work begins amidst the action.

The opening is considered in medias res because the protagonist has just left this geographic location. Camões personifies this place as a “grotesque and enormous” Titan with “unkempt beard” named Adamastor.

bonuses.leadin: Mrs. Norman Culver claimed that the Fox sisters, two central figures in this movement, produced “rapping noises” by snapping their toes in order to mimic the sounds of its central figures. For 10 points each:
answers: Spiritualism [do not accept or prompt on “Spiritism”]
Harry Houdini [or Erik Weisz or Ehrich Weiss or Harry Weiss]
parts: Name this religious movement that Arthur Conan Doyle was an ardent member of. A similarly named but distinct movement was founded by Allan Kardec.
This man had a falling out with Arthur Conan Doyle over the spiritualist movement. This magician died of a ruptured appendix after being punched in the stomach.

This president’s wife, Florence, was an ardent spiritualist who employed the medium Marcia Chaumphrey to expose plotters against her husband. Rumors at the time speculated that she may have had this president killed as revenge for his affair with Nan Britton.

bonuses.leadin: Oceanographer Charles J. Moore helped bring attention to this thing by sailing around the ocean in a raft made from an old fuselage from a Cessna airplane. For 10 points each:
answers: Great Pacific Garbage Patch [accept Eastern or Western Garbage Patch]
NOAA (“NO-uh”) [accept National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]
Nike (The incident is the “Great Shoe Spill of 1990.”) <WA, Other Academic>
parts: Give the common term for this large agglomeration of debris trapped in the North Pacific Gyre.
This US scientific agency operates the Marine Debris Program, which seeks to help clean up the Garbage Patch. It is known by a four-letter acronym and provides the National Weather Service.

Studies of Pacific garbage gained prominence after a 1990 incident in which the cargo ship Hansa spilled 61,000 of this company’s products into the ocean. Team Sweat organizes factory workers employed by this company in such locations as the Korean-run Hansae (“hahn-seh”) facility in Vietnam.

bonuses.leadin: The narrator of a 1959 novel asks “Why is forgetfulness the plague of” one of these locations that is inhabited by three characters representing the Abrahamic religions. For 10 points each:
answers: alley [accept alleyway; accept Midaq Alley; prompt on street]
Egypt [or Arab Republic of Egypt; or Miṣr; or Khēmi]
a plague [accept The Plague or La peste] <RK, Long Fiction>
parts: Name this type of location. In another novel, one of these locations is home to the barber Abbas, who is beaten to death by British soldiers after throwing a beer glass in the face of the prostitute Hamida.

Naguib Mahfouz (“na-GHEEB ma-FOOZ”) set the novels The Children of Gebelawi and Midaq Alley in the alleyways of this home country of his. Mahfouz wrote a trilogy set in this African country’s capital.

The protagonist of Mahfouz’s novel The Harafish, who is raised in an alley, retreats to a cave after one of these events. In another novel, Father Paneloux (“pan-LOO”) delivers a sermon claiming that God brought one of these events to Oran, Algeria.

bonuses.leadin: A ruler of this kingdom supposedly named the Canary Islands after hearing reports of the large amounts of dogs there. For 10 points each:
answers: Numidia [or Inumidenb; do not accept or prompt on “Nubia”]
parts: Name this kingdom home to Juba II. A cunning ruler of this kingdom had his rival Hiempsal killed and once referred to Rome as a “city for sale,” probably because he was repeatedly able to bribe its politicians.

The latter king of Numidia, Jugurtha, was captured by this Roman politician, helping bring this man to the forefront of Roman politics. He later issued many proscriptions against his political opponents.
This earlier commander employed many Numidian horsemen in his many victories against the Romans, which occurred after he led his multinational army in a successful crossing of the Alps.

bonuses.leadin: An April 2019 Nature paper showed that tumors with microsatellite instability are highly dependent on one of these proteins, WRN. For 10 points each:
answers: progeria [accept accelerated aging or premature aging or equivalents; prompt on aging]
parts: Name these proteins that are responsible for unwinding the DNA double helix during replication.

Patients with germline mutations in WRN suffer from Werner syndrome, which is distinguished by this condition. Mutations in the lamin A protein that prevent its de-farnesylation also result in this condition.
In Lynch syndrome, microsatellite instability is caused by mutations in this DNA repair pathway, which includes the proteins MLH1 and MSH2.

bonuses.leadin: The track “Countdown,” which uses the song “Tune-Up” as a contrafact, is centered around this technique. For 10 points each:
answers: Coltrane changes [prompt on changes; prompt on, but DO NOT REVEAL, Giant Steps changes]
string bass [or double bass or upright bass or acoustic bass or contrabass; do not accept “bass guitar”] <RK, Other Arts: Music>
parts: Name this technique in jazz that features three tonic centers separated by major thirds, such as B, G, and E-flat. It is often used as a four-bar substitution over the chord progression ii–V–I (“two five one”).
Coltrane changes entered mainstream jazz after their use on the difficult title track of this John Coltrane album, which also includes the songs “Naima” and “Mr. P.C.”
The title of “Mr. P.C.” refers to Paul Chambers, who played this string instrument on Giant Steps. With piano and drums, it forms a standard jazz trio.

bonuses.leadin: John Donne’s “The Canonization” claims “We’ll build in [these things] pretty rooms.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name these things. Dante Gabriel Rossetti analogized them to “a coin” whose “face reveals / The soul” in a poem that begins by declaring one of these things to be “a moment’s monument.”

In a sonnet, this Romantic poet advised a critic who was “mindless of its honours” to “Scorn not the sonnet.” He described hearing “old Triton blow his wreathèd horn” to close his sonnet “The World is Too Much With Us.”
Wordsworth’s “Scorn not the sonnet” claims “with this key / [this author] unlocked his heart.” This author’s Sonnet 18 asks “Shall I compare thee to a summer’s day?”

bonuses.leadin: The phase-space formulation of this theory is built on methods developed in classical mechanics. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this type of mechanics that deals with miniscule objects, as opposed to classical mechanics, which deals with macroscopic ones.
Formulations of both classical and quantum mechanics both make use of this mathematical operator, which gives the sum of kinetic and potential energies for all particles in the system.

The cross product, the commutator, and the Poisson (“pwah-SAWN”) bracket satisfy this mathematical identity, which states that the sum of all even permutations of bracket operations on variables a, b, and c must be zero.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about Marianne Williamson’s brand of spiritual “Judaism,” for 10 points each.
answers: transcendental [or word forms like transcendentalism; accept transcendental meditation]
parts: Williamson got her start as a mentor teaching a book called A Course in Miracles, which she popularized via this TV host and billionaire. This host’s “book club” also disseminated Rhonda Byrne’s The Secret.

Many ideas in Williamson’s book A Return to Love can be traced to Phineas Quimby’s New Thought, which was in turn influenced by a philosophy described by this adjective promoted in The Dial magazine. Maharishi Mahesh Yogi developed a mantra-based practice described by this adjective.

Williamson also derived influence from this doctor and fellow New Age spiritualist, a follower of the Transcendental Meditation movement who invented an alternative medicine system called “quantum healing.”

bonuses.leadin: A character in this play describes the “circular logic” of “looking at an Escher painting and getting all confused” in a monologue that ends “We ARE like this. WE are LIKE this.” For 10 points each:
answers: Tennessee Williams (That character is Blanche DuBois.)
parts: Name this work of documentary theatre organized by the Tectonic Theater Project. It consists of interviews with citizens of the title town surrounding the murder of an openly gay man.

Tectonic Theater Project founder Moisés Kaufman also adapted this author’s story about a male prostitute, titled “One Arm.” He created a teacher who leaves her plantation home shortly after discovering her husband Allan Grey’s homosexual affair, driving him to suicide.
Moisés Kaufman’s Gross Indecency fictionalizes the arrest of this Irish playwright for his relationship with Lord Alfred Douglas. He wrote The Importance of Being Earnest.

bonuses.leadin: This philosopher’s syndicalism called for workers to carry revolution via a “general strike.” For 10 points each:
answers: myths [or mythologies; accept myth of Er; prompt on legends]
parts: Name this French philosopher who argued that workers should avoid socialist political parties, as they might ally with conservatives to preserve national control, in the book Reflections on Violence.

George Sorel’s writings discuss the power of “social” and “national” examples of these stories. In a passage from The Republic commonly called one of these stories, a man describes how he dies in battle and witnesses the transmigration of souls.
George Sorel admired this philosopher, who theorized a “vanguard party” in his pamphlet What is to be Done? and later became the first leader of the Soviet Union.

bonuses.leadin: This author’s recent book 21 Lessons for the 21st Century suggests adopting the Scandinavian approach of protecting “workers, not jobs.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this historian whose book Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind postulates that humanity underwent a “cognitive revolution” about 70,000 years ago that allowed people to live in an “intersubjective reality.”

Harari postulates that a second “revolution” took place with the invention of this practice during the Neolithic period. Domestication of plants enabled this practice at such sites as Çatalhöyük (“cha-TALL-hoo-yook”).

Harari’s work draws on discoveries made by the Leakey family at this paleoanthropological site in Tanzania, such as the stone tools made by Paranthropus boisei (“puh-RAN-thruh-puss BOY-say”) and Homo habilis.

bonuses.leadin: This ruler was overthrown by the Red Eyebrows Rebellion following a massive flood. For 10 points each:
answers: Han Dynasty [accept Han chao] <ML, World History>
parts: Name this ruler who seized power, founded his own dynasty, and implemented a wide-ranging standardization program after a dynastic crisis created by Emperor Ai’s homosexuality.

The flood demonstrated that Wang Mang had “lost” this concept from Chinese historiography, which refers to the notion that a presiding dynasty has the right to rule as long as it demonstrates that it is worthy.
This dynasty, which was interrupted by Wang Mang’s reign, ruled from about 206 BC to 220 AD. This dynasty also names the majority ethnic group in China.

bonuses.leadin: A king of this city warred with his brother Proetus (“pro-EE-tuss”) in the womb and later sent a chest out to sea, which was recovered by the fisherman Dictys. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this city ruled by Acrisius, from which that chest containing Danaë (“DAN-ay”) was cast.
The chest containing Danaë also contained this son of hers, who ended up accidentally killing Acrisius with a discus. This hero married Andromeda and killed Medusa.

In another story from Argos, this pair of twins showed their devotion to their old mother by pulling a cart with her in it to a festival of Hera. Name either of these twins, whose devotion was rewarded by Hera with a peaceful and happy death.
